text: Despite its many oddities, *Between Dog and Wolf* features a strict, formal structure: eight prose chapters from the perspective of the itinerant grinder Ilya Zynzyrella; five prose chapters that concern the life and thoughts of the dog-keeper Yakov Palamakhterov; four chapters consisting of 36 poems written by Yakov; and a final chapter made up of a single, separate poem, again authored by Yakov. As Alexander Boguslawski writes, the chapters follow this pattern: ABCABACABACABACBAC ("How Sokolov's" 205).

The title of Ilya's chapters derives from the Tatar name of the Volga river (Itil'), and recalls the [Zadonshchina](http://www.drevne.ru/lib/zadon_s.htm), an epic literary text (dated late 14th century) about the Battle of Kulikovo of 1380 (its title derives from the river Don). As "the Zadonshchina shows the humanity of the Tatar troops and expresses genuine sympathy for a grief the Russian and Tatar alike could understand” (Halperin, *The Golden Horde *109), the Zaitil'shchina describes the diverse human universe by the Volga (Zavol'zhe), or Wolf river (Zavol'che) as it is called by paronomastic association between the terms Volga and "volk" (wolf). Andrei Zorin describes the setting of the novel in these terms: "in the second novel, the directly named Zaitil'shchina, or Zavolzh'e, serves only as a symbol for a lost corner of the earth. The specific topographical realities here are deliberately scarce, and the historical ones are so thoroughly mixed up that it is absolutely impossible to reconcile the events described with any particular part of our century. And this desire of the writer for the ultimate universalization of time and space in his novel finds its most vivid expression in the role played in his artistic world by the painting of Pieter Brueghel the Elder" ("Nasylaiushchii veter" 252); "The theme of physical damage in the novel becomes another embodiment of the Zaitil'shchina, a land where nothing is being built, produced, and only occasionally repaired, and more often it decays, becomes unusable, breaks and steals" ("Nasylaiushchii veter" 253). Vadim Kreid, titling his article "Zaitil'shchina," describes the "bezvremen'e" (the absence of time) as the "неизлечимая болезнь Заитильского бытия" (incurable illness of life in Zavol'zhe), while he also points out a specific "agnosticism" typical of this fictional world, based on "carelessness, inevitability of desolation, and nothingness (non-existence) as redemption" (беспечность, неизбежность опустошения и небытие как избавление) (216-217).

This expression hides a double meaning, as the word "mesiats" may mean both "moon" and "month". The author is at once suggesting that "the month is clear" (a rather indeterminate time setting) and that "the moon shines". The formulation recalls also Nikolai Gogol's *Diary of a Madman* (1834): "I don't remember the date. There was also no month" (Ostanin 10). The workers' cooperative (a joint venture) is in contrast with the "individuals" who work there. This pairing, in a sense, describes the novel's use of "forking characters" who constantly shift names and identities. For this reason, *Between Dog and Wolf* has often, though too simplistically been called the "Russian *Finnegans Wake*. For example, Richard Borden writes, "Aside from its perceived inaccessibility, its extremely disjointed narrative, its profound elusiveness and allusiveness, the fundamental timelessness of its narrative, its seeming to operate more according to the laws of dream than of waking experience, its wealth of neologism and, in particular, of complex paronomasia, *Between Dog and Wolf* resembles *Finnegans Wake* in its forking characters, in the way characters seem to dissolve one into the other—or evolve one from the other" ("Toward" 389).

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310).Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Peterburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).

text: A variation of the set expression "vlezt' v shkuru" (get under the skin), meaning "to put oneself into one's shoes". As Johnson notes, Ilya Zynzyrella, evoking "Cinderella of vair (or verre) slipper fame" is indeed "a male Cinderella [who] makes fur slippers for his beloved who (posthumously) seeks to be reunited with him." He adds: "If the fur slippers are central to the intergrading of Orina and the mentally defective girls, valenki 'felt boots' strongly hint at the relationship between Il'ya and Yakov. Once there, he begins to shine with light, and Elijah (one of Ilya's identities in the novel) and Moses appear beside him as the voice of God calls out to him. The event is documented in [Matthew 17:1–8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%2017%3A1-8&version=NIV), [Mark 9:2–8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Mark%209%3A2-8&version=NIV), and [Luke 9:28–36](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke%209%3A28-36&version=NIV). Celebrated on August 6. The main character of Mikhail Bulgakov's *Heart of a Dog* (a novel which widely circulated in samizdat in the 60s) is Doctor Preobrazhensky, whose experiment of turning a homeless dog into a man leads to tragic consequences (and to his "transfigurating" back into a dog). text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars."Olga Matich writes: "If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Peterburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).

text: Throughout the novel, geese are associated with sexual arousal. Here, they are linked to the Dama's appearance in the hunters' company. Although today far more commonly considered silly or stupid, geese have a lofty mythology. The goose has been traditional viewed as “an erotic symbol for both sexes, because it was the bird of creation, whether in the male solar form of the gods or the female lunar form of the mother goddesses" (Rowland 68). Similar connections between geese, sexuality, and foolishness appear elsewhere in the novel (R210, 221/E106, 125). Animal-bird motif.
ru_trans: На протяжении романа, гуси ассоциируются с сексуальным возбуждением. Здесь, они связаны с появлением Дамы в компании охотников. Несмотря на современное восприятие гусей как глупых существ, мифологическая история этих птиц весьма благородна. Гуси традиционно воспринимались как "эротический символ обоих полов, будь то в форме солнца, олицетворяющего мужских богов, или луны, олицетворяющей богинь-матерей" (Б. Роуленд). Подобные связи между гусями, сексуальностью и глупостью встречаются далее в романе (R210, 221/E106, 125).

text: "Мать - сыра земля" - это персонифицированный образ земли в славянской мифологии. Это тоже название повести Бориса Пильняка (1925). "Moist Mother Earth" is the personified representation of the earth in Slavic mythology. It is also the title of a povest' by Boris Pil'nyak (1925). Olga Matich already pointed out at the similarities between Pil'nyak's text "about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War" and *Between Dog and Wolf*: "It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story's many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina's maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf" ("Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context" 312).

text: Derived from the colloquial невтерпёж (lacking patience). Here, Ilya suggests that his relations with Orina were going smoothly and patiently (i.e., calmly) for some time. Alexander Boguslawski notes that variations on this word are used in four key moments in the novel (R155, 157, 225, 254/E12, 14–15, 132, 185) and that the "close parallels between the first and last use of the phrase should be noted — this is the frame within which two other versions of the expression exist. These two framing elements are built around the word *nevterpezh*, a colloquial adverb, usually used after a noun or pronoun in dative case and often with auxiliary verbs to be or to become. Thus, the expression "mne stalo nevterpezh" [it became unbearable to me; I could not stand it any longer], [sic] is common. However, Sokolov makes some important alterations to the expression — first, he discards the dative government and substitutes another verb for the auxiliary" ("How Sokolov's" 218).

text: An allusion to the prison song "Taganka." The title refers to the Taganka Prison in Moscow, which housed numerous political prisoners in both tsarist and Soviet times. The lights were never turned off in the prison, hence the line "полные огня" ("full of fire"). The prison was demolished in 1960. Read the lyrics [here](https://lyricstranslate.com/en/taganka-taganka-taganka.html). Listen to a recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ih0WLzvZjuY). text: Sokolov has written about his desire to avoid the "what" in literature," opting for the "how": “In the milieu from which I come […] the traditions of so-called art-for-art’s sake are still alive. text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (*gorod*) and beggar (*nishchii*). It is the "town of beggars."Olga Matich writes: "If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Peterburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
